newsitem.title: BRAZIL: CPFL says Jan-May energy consumption up.
newsitem.headline: CPFL says Jan-May energy consumption up.

text.p: Sao Paulo state power firm Cia Paulista de Forca e Luz (CPFL) said electricity consumption in its concession area rose 8.9 percent in 1997's first five months versus the same period last year.
CPFL also said in a statement that May power consumption was 2.1 percent higher than the same month last year and up six percent from April.
The company said 1.39 million megawatt-hours (MWh) of energy was consumed last month, bringing to 7.26 million MWh the amount of electricity consumed from January through May.
The number of days in the five-month period this year, however, was 154 compared with 149 days in January-May 1996, so the real hike in power consumption over the period was 5.4 percent, it added.
Industry was responsible for 40.7 percent of the total, consuming 2.96 million MWh in the first five months, up 10.4 percent from the same period last year, CPFL said.
May industrial consumption reached 558,994 MWh, up 1.5 percent from May 1996 and 7.6 percent from April.
Residential consumption, which accounted for 29.8 percent of CPFL's sales, climbed to 2.16 million MWh in the January-May period, an eight percent rise from the same period last year, it said.
The sector's consumption reached 416,562 MWh in May, up 1.9 percent from the same month last year and down 5.1 percent from April, it added.
Commercial consumption, which made up 13.5 percent of the total, increased 10.1 percent to 979,319 MWH in the five-month period versus the same period in 1996, the statement said.
May's commercial consumption rose to 181,157 MWh, a 2.1 percent hike from May 1996 and a 9.2 percent drop from April.
CPFL gained 7,112 new customers last month, bringing its constomer base to 2,381,169, up 4.5 percent from May 1996.
CPFL, considered by analysts to be the jewel of the Sao Paulo electrical sector, is expected to be sold by October in the first sell-off in Sao Paulo state's privatization program.
